meanings.definition: To diminish or destroy the quality or value of something.
meanings.sent1: Leaving food out in the sun can start spoiling it.
meanings.sent2: She was worried about spoiling the surprise party.
meanings.sent3: The rain began spoiling the outdoor picnic.
meanings.sent4: His negative attitude was spoiling the mood of the group.
meanings.sent5: The mold was slowly spoiling the bread on the shelf.

meanings.definition: To pamper or indulge someone excessively.
meanings.sent1: Grandma enjoys spoiling her grandchildren with treats.
meanings.sent2: He couldn't resist spoiling his pet with new toys.
meanings.sent3: The wealthy heiress loved spoiling herself with luxurious vacations.
meanings.sent4: The celebrity's entourage was spoiling her with constant attention.
meanings.sent5: The spa weekend was a way of spoiling herself after a long week.

meanings.definition: The act of causing something to deteriorate or decay.
meanings.sent1: The spoiling of the fruit was evident from the foul smell.
meanings.sent2: He noticed the spoiling of the wooden fence due to neglect.
meanings.sent3: The spoiling of the milk made it undrinkable.
meanings.sent4: The spoiling of relationships can happen if trust is broken.
meanings.sent5: The spoiling of the environment is a serious concern for conservationists.
